segments.text: Right.
I'm ready.
This is Alan Vine speaking.
Perhaps one of the most important things to talk about next that affected some of our business and certainly the kind of work I was doing was when Thrasher sank.
This was in the spring of
1963, a most unfortunate event.
Our ship, a real few hours after it sank, I believe it was Art Maxwell from ONR called me up.
let me know what had happened.
Our ship, the Atlantis that was Atlantis II that was on its maiden voyage, was operating up in the Gulf of Maine only about 50 miles away.
We were able to get it detoured, get hold of it and get it detoured over.
and got messages off to that as to where the ship was, what kind of equipment was aboard, and what they might be able to do.
And the ship was basically at his service in any way that he could use it.
But meanwhile, it would go about doing oceanographic surveys of the area until told to do something else.
There are several parts about the Thresher sinking which were important to oceanography.
One, the whole oceanographic game had gotten much larger than it was during the war and after the war.
It had gotten much more bureaucratic.
Organizations had naturally gotten much more self-centered.
Individuals had tended to get more self-centered.
And many of us had commented on whether that spirit of cooperation that was exhibited during World War II would ever show again.
Here at Woods Hole, it certainly did.
We got calls from a great many places, for example, Bucky Buchanan
NRL called up and said, you're the closest laboratory to the ship.
We don't know what will happen, but it's almost certain that your place will tend to be a headquarters.
I've loaded two trucks, 10-ton trucks up with equipment that you might be able to use, and it's on its way.
A representative of the Texas National Guard called up
and said, we understand you people are involved in the search, and some of it's being based out of Woods Hole.
We want you to know the Texas National Guard has the following kinds of aircraft.
Any of these are available at any time, any place, any job.
This number will be a good 24 hours a day.
A taxi driver who was supposed to pick up a piece of apparatus in Boston and bring it down hadn't shown up in the two and a half hours.
We were getting a little disgusted when he arrived at the laboratory.
His taxi had broken down halfway down here, and he left to the side of the road and hitchhiked down with a package because he felt it was needed.
This kind of cooperation went on throughout the Thrasher search.
and by a great many people, a great many places.
And it was one of the positive things that came out of the search.
It made us all realize that when the crunch comes, people will cooperate.
At a fairly early date, within a few days after the Thrasher sank and the Navy had appointed
Captain Frank Andrews to be the on-scene commander.
Frank called me up to see if I would join him basically as his technical advisor.
He had been in the Submarine Development Group 2 in New London.
which I want to say something else about later.
I forgot that important place.
And he wanted to have someone both as a technical aide and also someone who was sufficiently acquainted with the oceanographic community so that he would know where we could get more help.
All of the laboratories that had ships converged on the area.
This is not the place to try and describe the Thresher search, except to say that about five ships were involved intermittently from the laboratories.
Each technique that was felt to be promising was whipped out, utilized as well as practical.
And then when either those people got tired out or they lost their gear, why then another ship would come in to continue or try another technique.
There are many lessons to be learned in that.
in that unfortunate affair.
After being on scene about two weeks, the Chief of Naval Operations set up a committee under Admiral Ed Steffen, who had been oceanographer of the Navy and had been a very important person in
re-cementing the relationships between the oceanographic community and the Navy's oceanographic office.
So I left the unseen part of the Thrasher search and went to Washington and joined in with a committee which varied from anywhere between 10 and 30 people, depending upon the times,

see what one, really to write up a plan and a set of recommendations for the Navy as to how the search should be conducted, the rescue should be attempted, salvage should be undertaken, and so forth, if such a thing happened again.
This committee went on at rather full strength and high steam
about two and a half months.
And at least that much longer was taken in sort of writing it up and assembling it.
The best people in the country that were knowledgeable in such subjects were brought together in that committee.
And a rather extensive report was put out
Unfortunately, most of that report was classified, because it had to do so much with submarine operations.
But the general principles came out in a wide variety of reports by individuals who had attended the meetings.
Bad days in Washington then was when we were at the Naval Gun Factory was the news that Kennedy had been assassinated.
And like nearly all other activities and groups in Washington, one just kind of shook your head and went home for a while.
Okay, let's start in here.
One, to backtrack a bit in the late 50s, the Academy of Sciences
under the chairmanship of Harrison Brown, had a third National Academy of Sciences Committee on Oceanography.
Harrison had asked me if I would chair a panel on equipment, which ended up by being called the Panel on New Devices.
And I had the very great pleasure of being chairman of that.
being involved with that.
And Harrison took the attitude that he wanted his panel chairman tohe hoped they would attend all meetings and that they would
also feel free to cast votes on all problems in which they legally could.
And he didn't want to run the committee in such a fashion that there would be votes in which it wasn't perfectly legal for them to do so.
As an individual, this gave me an opportunity to work even more closely with
with many fine oceanographers that I already knew very well, but it also permitted me to get acquainted with quite a few more oceanographers that I didn't know very well.
This committee can be described a little bit as taking about, there were about 30 three-day weekend meetings in which work was the
was the general tenor and that usually included about two of those knights.
That committee in which Harrison Brown did such a good job of keeping
keeping his eye on the ball of not only what needed to be done, but also very much how it had to be managed and done.
And he was as much interested in the congressional aspect of it as he was in the oceanographic aspect.
In other words, the chairman's concern, to a large extent, was how do science and government work together.
One of the more interesting and lovable people on the committee was Sumner Pike, who had been one of the original members of the Atomic Energy Commission.
He came from an old fishing family up in Lubeck, Maine.
And perhaps his stature and personality could

be best described by saying that a couple of times I saw him sort of talk to Ewing and Revelle and Islin as though they were a little bit small boys, and he did it in such a lovely style that they took it just like nice small boys should take it.
Sumner had a wealth of experience in politics, mining, fishing, and just human nature.
Everybody on that committee, I think, felt that they probably learned as much from Sumner as from anybody else.
But to get back to perhaps the more
to somewhat the more technical points that I was involved with.
The committee of about half a dozen people, Jim Snodgrass from Scripps, Jim Lipp, who was corporate
head of corporate planning for Lockheed, kindly took membership because he thought it would be a very interesting thing to do.
And while he was more used to working in millions rather than thousands, his good common sense and his larger perspective was extremely important.
Bob Frosch was a member and Andreas Rechnitzer.

The goal for that particular piece of chapter was to try and see what kind of equipments were going to be necessary and optimum to carry out oceanography, both at a larger scale and also with a great deal more finesse.
Here was another place to inject the fact that ships were needed, a logical array of ships.
There was a ship chapter, which I spent a great deal of time on.
Also, the question of navigation was very important.
And I would like to mention one aspect of that
which is perhaps an example of how things frequently get done.
It was well known that the Navy was operating with or working on a transit navigation system, which was classified.
And oh, I can't think of the fellow's name from
John Hopkins University, who did the primary work on that.
But he came up to Woods Hole and gave a lecture on the principles of the system.
And he felt very strongly that one might be able to make a much simpler transit navigational receiver if one was willing to put up with a correspondingly larger error.
Well, oceanographers who didn't have very good navigation, and when you wander around a week or two in the fog, your navigation is almost non-existent, anything looked very good to us.
The Navy Department officially wanted to have no real part of this.
They felt that their prize people should be sticking on to the
under their job.
Not that they were really against it so much, but they wanted progress in their own field.
What our committee conjured up was the following concept.
We would write the director of each of the larger oceanographic institutions to see if they would be willing to commit a sum of twenty thousand dollars
for an experimental navigational transit system in which there was no guarantee as to how precise it would be.
There was no guarantee as to whether it would work at all.
And there was no guarantee as to whether they would ever even get it.

We sent this out, and in his usual exhilaration to move forward, Ewing had his letter back in about 48 hours from Lamont and said that if it was permissible to ask for two, he would guarantee $40,000, one for each ship.
Well, armed with guarantees of $100,000, we could then go to the
We could then go to the John Hopkins group.
They, in turn, could go to the Navy and say that we now have enough money to do the design work if you will permit us to work on it.

This got us over enough of an administrative hurdle to where those in the Navy that thought it was a fine idea could win, and they gave him authorization to go ahead, providing it didn't interfere with his other work.
It turned out that the design of these went very rapidly and very well, and soon they became available for oceanographers to use.
In actuality, the Navy, of course, did not want to take our $20,000 apiece because that would have had some obligation that we could then keep it.
So they just loaned us the units to use, and our $100,000 bluff paid off.
We not only got free instruments, but...
It also turned out that a new instrument had been developed for the oceanographic game.
This was parlayed on further at the international oceanographic meeting that was going to be held in Europe.
Dr. Wakelin, who was then Under Secretary of the Navy,
cooperated very much on this, as he was at many levels of research, and he was staying in close contact with oceanography and the Oceanographic Committee.
He got authorization to announce at this international meeting that these equipments that we had that had been built for American oceanography were going to be made available to the world at large.
And this was one of the major breakthroughs in civilian navigation.
Since that time, the equipments have become much smaller, much simpler, much cheaper, and much more accurate.
And they are now sort of the standard navigational, the most standard navigational system for high seas navigation.

I also want to add here that the man in the committee that carried the ball principally on this was Jim Snodgrass, but it was one of the kinds of things that all of us spent a great deal of time on because we felt it was so important that it was worthwhile dropping almost any other problem if that one needed carried along.
The general problem of how one uses, how one probably used buoys at sea was
and how one gets financed for developing buoys for sea and using buoys for measurement at sea received great impetus from this.
Buoys, we had used buoys at Woods Hole a good deal.
I had used some.
Many others had.
Scripps was using them.
primarily in the weapons test to measure fallout on the Pacific.
Had I mentioned that earlier?
I think this deserves a little special merit because at Woods Hole, there was the great tendency to look at buoys as a way to make subsurface measurements.

At Scripps, there was more of a tendency to use them for making measurements of nuclear fallout after the tests, so they were more interested in the surface phenomena, but they were also interested in a very much larger area, in huge areas of the Pacific.

these effects and trends showed up because in later years the Scripps buoy program covered large sections of the Pacific and being more surface oriented they made cheaper buoys and they got more out that had to do with surface phenomena and meteorological phenomena and these served as

a large part of the database in which the magnificent work that, under the sponsorship of Jerome Nimaeus, was later able to carry out in weather prediction, the influence of large-scale eddies and temperature anomalies in the Pacific.
This, I think, was one of the fallouts, eventual fallouts, of that program.
which certainly was not predictable in detail, but was predictable in the sense that Bowie feels would make it possible to do things like this.
And from the standpoint of the world at large, this has probably been by all odds the most important contribution of Bowie's to date.
And it's one part of it that I think all of us who were on that committee felt very good about.
Also in this era, our technological approach of working on the nuts and bolts of research had helped produce budgets and ships and was doing this.
we had simple buoys on the way.
It was also very important to try and get a, see how stable you could make a ship.
There's nothing in Newton's laws that says ships have to rock and roll, and at a somewhat earlier date, I had been down in New London one time looking at
the two submarine hulls, which had been completed during the war and nothing had been put in them.
And it certainly appeared that there should be a better use for those submarine hulls than going into razor blades.
And so one bitter cold night driving back to New London coming through Taunton, I suddenly came to that if you put one of those on end, that...
the natural heave period would be longer than that of the waves, and it should be a very stable platform.

Pieces of this, I guess without any question, were original with me, but the fundamental thinking about it was on wave measurement buoys, which had been built by a variety of people and had been pushed very hard
John Holmes, a technical man who had been working with us and with me at Woods Hole.
Anyhow, I did get a report out on that, and it was one of the kinds of things that quite a few oceanographers talked about as a good thing to do.
Well, we pushed this sort of a stable platform in our committee.
We didn't know just when it would get done, but the principles were there.
How do we get a technical base for oceanography that is commensurate with the improved fiscal base and the large number of fine new people that were coming into the business?
And one of the things that the increase in money did is it produced, it gave not only new people, but it started bringing in people from other fields.
And as such, the game became somewhat less incestuous than it had been before.
Actually, in following this stable buoy program up, a few years later, in a committee called
Navy committee called the Stag Committee, which was, its purpose was to see if sound went straight under the ocean.
And if you ever tried to find a target with a piece of sonar gear, would it actually be where you thought it was going to be?
Well, it was necessary to make some very precise horizontal measurements.
And one of the key committee members
Fred Spies from Scripps was involved in this.
So what we did is we dusted out the earlier tentative proposals for a vertical spar buoy.
He got a contract and did design work and turned it into what is now known as FLIT, which has been amazingly successful.
Flip is a nice illustration of a basic concept that has been kicking around for heaven knows for how long.
Holmes and others had put it into very effective use for measurement programs on a small scale of 10 to 20 feet long.
I thought of taking something as crude as a submersible hole, which is of course not too crude, and doing it with that.
And had certainly intended that it would be rotated so that you could operate it horizontally
and then flip it up.
But what Spiess and the Scripps crowd did was they put in that lovely piece of finesse to build it so it could be flipped several times during a day if needed.
So if there was something wrong with it, something wrong with the bottom, you could flip it up and fix it.
And that was one of the things that made it truly operational.
So you could bring it into port every night if you wanted to.
I hope we will see
much more of stable ships, because I'm sure it is ridiculous to always bounce and rock and roll on the surface, just because most ships are designed to rock and roll, and sure enough, they do.
Let's shut it off.
one of the chapters of this report had to do with the disposal of nuclear waste had to do with radioactivity in the ocean of which some of the

And at that stage of the game, it was very apparent that radioactivity in the ocean was not being looked at as hard as it should be, that the high level waste products would almost certainly require much more
much more knowledge about their fate and what one might do with them, engineering-wise, than had been done.
Atomic Energy Commission had informal representatives in the group.
They worked very well.
Ravel was particularly interested in this problem, as was Benny Schaefer.

There was some discussion as to whether submersibles shouldn't be in a much wider variety of uses here, and whether the Atomic Energy Commission shouldn't be one of the sponsors of submersibles, because that would be one of the ways to determine the fates of radioactivity in the bottom.
